references: Even though we address the Gaussian DP-noise exploitation in the context of GDP-based FL in [22], a method has not been devised yet in the literature to keep the attack persistent, robust, and stealthy, especially in â„’â„’\mathcal{L}-DPFL. If the attack is not persistent throughout the communication episodes, the random node selection method that almost every state-of-the-art FL processes adopt nowadays may cancel out any adversarial contribution. Moreover, if the attack is non-robust, the attack impact would be negligible. We show evidence of achieving attack stealthiness, persistence, and robustness in this paper. Table II summarizes the comparison with the most related works discussed above.

references:
To experimentally evaluate our proposed attack and defense policy, we use a smart grid dataset (Individual household electric power consumption dataset [46]). Table III enlist some of the important features of the dataset. Although the dataset contains 1.251.251.25% missing records, the size of the dataset (2,075,25920752592,075,259 records) is sufficient for the practical demonstration purpose of our model. For â„’â„’\mathcal{L}-DPFL environment, we select the parameters as stated in Table IV.
We perform the experiments on a lambda tensorbook with 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i777-118001180011800H @2.302.302.30GHz CPU, RTX 308030803080 Max-Q GPU, 646464 GB RAM, 222 TB storage, Windows 101010 pro (646464-bit) OS, Python 3.9.73.9.73.9.7, and PyTorch 1.10.0+limit-from1.10.01.10.0+cpu.

To experimentally evaluate our proposed attack and defense policy, we use a smart grid dataset (Individual household electric power consumption dataset [46]). Table III enlist some of the important features of the dataset. Although the dataset contains 1.251.251.25% missing records, the size of the dataset (2,075,25920752592,075,259 records) is sufficient for the practical demonstration purpose of our model. For â„’â„’\mathcal{L}-DPFL environment, we select the parameters as stated in Table IV.
We perform the experiments on a lambda tensorbook with 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i777-118001180011800H @2.302.302.30GHz CPU, RTX 308030803080 Max-Q GPU, 646464 GB RAM, 222 TB storage, Windows 101010 pro (646464-bit) OS, Python 3.9.73.9.73.9.7, and PyTorch 1.10.0+limit-from1.10.01.10.0+cpu.

references: To defend the DP-exploited stealthy model poisoning attacks, the privacy level for the nodes needs to be chosen carefully during the design phase. Too much privacy leads to poor model performance and a wider poisoning window, whereas, very little privacy can expose the confidential and crucial operating information of the grid. To demonstrate the scenario, we perform several experiments for multiple values of the RL parameters. The results are presented in Table V. It can be inferred that for every discount factor, Î¶ğœ\zeta (except Î¶=1.00ğœ1.00\zeta=1.00), at every level of learning rate (Î±ğ›¼\alpha), Î”â€‹Qâ€‹(s,i)Î”ğ‘„ğ‘ ğ‘–\Delta Q(s,i) value is almost zero when the learning ends. However, the average global reward, Rğ‘…R varies largely with the change of Î¶ğœ\zeta. The maximum reward is achieved when the learning rate, Î±=0.001ğ›¼0.001\alpha=0.001, and the discount factor, Î¶=0.50ğœ0.50\zeta=0.50 ensures that the agent not only cares for the present reward but also considers the future reward equally.
